review.title: Boost Phrase-level Polarity Labelling with Review-level Sentiment Classification
review.abstract: Sentiment analysis on user reviews helps to keep track of user reactions towards products, and make advices to users about what to buy. State-of-the-art review-level sentiment classification techniques could give pretty good precisions of above 90%. However, current phrase-level sentiment analysis approaches might only give sentiment polarity labelling precisions of around 70%~80%, which is far from satisfaction and restricts its application in many practical tasks. In this paper, we focus on the problem of phrase-level sentiment polarity labelling and attempt to bridge the gap between phrase-level and review-level sentiment analysis. We investigate the inconsistency between the numerical star ratings and the sentiment orientation of textual user reviews. Although they have long been treated as identical, which serves as a basic assumption in previous work, we find that this assumption is not necessarily true. We further propose to leverage the results of review-level sentiment classification to boost the performance of phrase-level polarity labelling using a novel constrained convex optimization framework. Besides, the framework is capable of integrating various kinds of information sources and heuristics, while giving the global optimal solution due to its convexity. Experimental results on both English and Chinese reviews show that our framework achieves high labelling precisions of up to 89%, which is a significant improvement from current approaches.

metadata.title: Boost Phrase-level Polarity Labelling with Review-level Sentiment Classification∗∗∗

sections.text: Boost Phrase-Level Polarity Labeling with Review-Level Sentiment Classification - Yongfeng Zhang Department of Computer Science Tsinghua University yongfeng14 @ mails.tsinghua.edu.cnMin Zhang Department of Computer Science Tsinghua University z-m @ tsinghua.edu.cnYiqun Liu Department of Computer Science Tsinghua University yiqunliu @ tsinghua.edu.cnShaoping Ma Department of Computer Science Tsinghua University msp @ tsinghua.edu.cnSentiment analyses on user reviews could help track users "reactions to products and provide advice to users on what to buy. State-of-the-art review-level classification techniques could provide pretty good precision of over 90%. However, the current phrase-level sensitivity analysis could only help to focus the polarity of labeling on the level of around 70%, which is far from increasing its practicality in terms of 80%.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Sentiment analysis techniques could be classified into three levels according to the different granularities on which the analysis is conducted, i.e., document-level, sentencelevel and phrase-level (Liu and Zhang 2012). In analyzing user reviews, documentlevel sentiments analysis is also referent as review-level sentiments analysis (Figure 1 shows a user review on an Apple iPhone product, which is extracted from Amazon.com, and the third author is supported by Natural Science Foundation (60903107, 61073071) and National High Technology Research and Development (863) Program (2011A01A205) of China, and the third author is sponsored by the National Science Foundation (IIS-0713111).

sections.heading: 2. Related work
sections.text: With the rapid growth of e-commerce, social networks, and online discussion forums, the Web is rich in user-generated free-text data, in which users express different attitudes toward products or events that have attracted researchers in Sentiment Analysis (Liu and Zhang 2012; Pang and Lee 2008).Sentiment analysis plays an important role in many applications, including opinion retrieval (Orimaye, Alhashmi, and Siew 2013), mouth-to-mouth tracking (Jansen et al. 2009), and opinion-based document summary (Liu, Seneff, and Zue 2010; Hu and Liu 2004), etc.One of the core tasks in sentiment analysis is to determine the sentiment orientations that users express in ratings, judgments, or specific product characteristics that are evaluated at the evaluation level (Pang, Lee, and Vaithyanathan 2002), Sentencelevel (Wiebe, Caragaauri, and Inagahinger), and Wilson.

sections.heading: 3. Problem Formalization
sections.text: In this section, we formalize the problems to be examined, as well as the notations to be used in this paper. Definition (sentiment vector) Suppose we consider sentimental polarity labels S1, S2 · · SR, for example, positive and negative feelings, if R = 2. A sentiment vector x = [x1, x2,..., xr] T (xi) represents the sentiment orientation of a review, sentence or feature opinion pair. The i-th element xi in x indicates the extent of sentiment on the i-th polarity label Si. A function s: Rr → R is defined on sentiment x so that s (x) represents the general mood of the review, sentence or feature opinion pair. For example, if S1 = positive and S2 = negative words, if R = 2, a sentiment vector = 1, [0] a sentiment T is used to indicate an orientation on a review.

sections.heading: 4. The Framework
sections.text: In general, the framework consists of two phases. In the first phase, we use an unattended algorithm to classify mood at level C to obtain the sentiment matrix X = C (T) for the verification corpus T; in the second phase, we extract feature opinion pairs from corpus T and use the sentiment matrix X and the general sentiment lexicon X0 in a uniform optimization framework to obtain the contextual sentiment lexicon X. After that, a predefined function s (X) is used to determine the general sentiment orientation of each feature opinion pair. We will present the details of the framework in the following part of the section.

sections.heading: 4.1 Review-Level Sentiment Classification
sections.text: The aim of this step is to present the general sentiment polarities of user reviews through sentiment classification algorithms; the first is to avoid the manual review review process at the review level of sentiment polarities, which makes our framework adaptable; the second is to keep our framework as general as possible to ensure its independence from specific data requirements; the optimization framework in (Lu et al. 2011) uses the numerical ratings of users in online shopping or review service websites to monitor the process of phrase-level sentiment labeling; such numerical ratings may not exist in specific environments, for example, in forum discussions, e-mails and newsgroups (Liu and Zhang 2012); and finally, the relationship between sentiment orientations of ratings and user reviews is still open (Moghadam and Ester).

sections.heading: 4.2 Sentiment Lexicon Construction
sections.text: In this phase, we construct the contextual sentiment lexicon. First, we create the feature opinion pairs and label their polarities in a uniform optimization framework.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Generation of Feature-Opinion Pairs.
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to trump themselves, and they are able to trump themselves. (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. "(...) Most of them have trumped themselves." (...) Most of them are able to trump themselves. "(...)

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Constraints on Sentiment Polarity Labelling.
sections.text: In this step, we try to establish a unique sentiment polarity (positive or negative) in order to be able to represent each individual sentiment review the intuition of a specific source of information. In addition, the loss function is expected to develop a quick and easy optimization algorithm to find the unique global optimal solution to the problem.

sections.heading: 4.2.3 The Unified Model for Polarity Labelling.
sections.text: With the above limitations of various information and aspects, we have the following objective function to learn the contextual sentiment lexicon X: min X ≥ 0 R = λ1 х AX − X-X-2F + λ2-G (X − XTDX) − Tr (XTWaX) − Tr (XTWbXE))) + λ4 (Tr (XTDsX) − Tr (XTWsX)) (13), whereby it is possible to search for the global optimal solution X-2, λ3 and λ4 positive balancing parameters that control the contributions of each source of information in the learning process. An important property of the objective function (13) is its convexity, which makes it possible to search for the global optimal solution X-1 to the contextual sentiment polarity problem.

sections.heading: 4.2.4 Overall Sentiment Polarity of the Pairs.
sections.text: After constructing the contextual sentiment lexicon X, we use the predefined function s (X) = [s (x1) s (x2) · · s (xn)] T to determine the sentiment polarities of the feature opinion pairs. In this thesis, we choose the function s (xi) = xi1 − xi2, where xi1 and xi2 are the values of positive and negative polarity names in the sentiment vector xi, respectively. Pair i is considered positive if s (xi) ≥ 0 and negative if s (xi) < 0. For simplicity, we omit the polarity designation from neutral like most of the existing work, since it is quite rare that xi1 = xi2.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we will conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the proposed framework and examine the effects of different parameter settings in our framework. We will try to answer the following two research questions: 1. Do numerical star ratings always correspond to the general mood orientation of textual user ratings? 2. How effective is our proposed framework compared to other methods of polarity labeling? First, we will present the experimental settings and then examine the relationship between numerical ratings and text ratings. Finally, we will evaluate the proposed framework and make some comparisons with other techniques.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: For the experiment in English, we use the MP3 player ratings from Amazon, which are publicly available.4 For the experiment in Chinese, we use the restaurant ratings from DianPing.com 5, a famous restaurant ratings website in China.6 Each of the ratings from the two records consists of a piece of review text and a general numerical rating ranging from 1 to 5 stars.We choose these two records from both English and Chinese, as these two languages are linguistically of very different types.We want to investigate whether our framework works in different language environments. Some statistical information about these two records is shown in Table 1.Table 1.1.Some statistics of the two datasets.Language # Users # Items # Reviews MP3 Player English 26,113 796 55,740 Restaurant Chinese 11,857 89,462 510,5514 http: / / sifaka.cus.iu / reviews MP3 Player English 26,796 55,740 Restaurant Chinese 11,810,462 510,5514 http: / / siced.ucedu / reviews of the three restaurants are required for the evaluation: http: / fact.ucedu / iu / idi.6

sections.heading: 5.2 User Rating Analysis
sections.text: Previous papers (Cui, Mittal and Datar 2006; Lu et al. 2011; Wang, Lu and Zhai 2010) refer to a review text as positive if the corresponding overall rating is 4 or 5 stars, and negative if the overall rating is 1, 2 or 3 stars. However, the overall rating may not always correspond to the emotional orientation of review texts. Our observation is that a significant number of users tend to give unchanged overall ratings, although the mood orientation expressed in his or her review text may vary. Interestingly, many users simply rate 4 stars regardless of the review text he has written. We will analyze this phenomenon in the following part of this section.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Overall and Sub-Aspect Ratings.
sections.text: We start by analyzing the difference in the distribution of the review aspects of the restaurant data set. The reviews on three partial aspects allow us to examine the "true" feelings of a user on more specific aspects of the restaurant beyond the overall rating. For the overall rating and each of the partial reviews, we calculate the percentages that each of the 5-star reviews takes into account in the total number of reviews, as shown in Figure 2. The x-axis represents 1 star above 5 stars, and the y-axis is the percentage of each type of star rating. We see that the user reviews tend to circulate in the overall rating by 4 stars, while they tend to center around 2-3 stars on the partial reviews. This implies that the overall rating may not serve as a true reflection of the feelings of users, and the users tend to be in much more detailed parts of "the truth tell" the users. To represent the overall statistical total = the overall importance of the overall rating, we examine the average and the GP, where we are.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Labelling Accuracy using Different Methods.
sections.text: In fact, users could consider many other features besides taste, environment and service when giving the overall ratings, as a result, it can be argued that the difference in the distribution of ratings on different aspects is not sufficient to imply that the overall rating is inappropriate to estimate the general mood of the review texts. As a result, we evaluate the impact of the sentiment orientation of review texts with different types of numerical ratings. We randomly assigned 1000 reviews out of the 510,551 reviews of restaurant reviews that are manually labeled 3 annotators. An annotator is asked to give a single label for a review text that could be positive or negative. The final sentiment of a review is assigned by using the majority label (more than two) of the three annotators. The inter-annotator agreement is 79.76%, which is comparable to the reports of the existing sentiment analysis (Pang and Lee 2008; Lu et al 2011).

sections.heading: 5.3 Feature-Opinion Pair Extraction
sections.text: There are three experimentally set parameters in the process of feature opinion pair extraction, which are 1) the minimum term frequency (referred to by freq) of NounPhrases to be selected as the candidate feature words, 2) the minimum pointwise mutual information (referred to by pmi) of a feature word candidate to be maintained during the filtering process, and 3) the minimum co-occurrence ratio (referred to by cor) of a pair to be selected as the last feature opinion pair.Pool Lexicon: In principle, we have used relatively strict parameters to obtain a high quality feature opinion pairs, which allow us to focus on the core task of phrase evaluation polarity marking in this thesis. After careful parameter selection, we set freq = 10, pmi = 0.005, cor = 0.05 on the mp3 player dataset, which leaves us with 1063 pairs, and tq = 20, 00pmi = 0.05 on restoration.

sections.heading: 5.4 Phrase-Level Polarity Labelling
sections.text: In this section, we perform an automatic mood polarity marking of the feature opinion pairs in the pool lexicon and report on the evaluation results of our method and the comparison methods.

sections.heading: 5.4.1 Evaluation Measures.
sections.text: We select the commonly used measurements Precision, Recall and F-Measure to evaluate the performance of the polarity marking, which are defined as follows: precision = Np _ agree Nlexicon, Recall = Ng _ agree Ngold, F-Measure = 2 · precision · Recall precision + Recall, where Nlexicon is the number of feature opinion pairs in the automatically constructed Mood Encyclopaedia and Ngold is the number of pairs in the Gold Standard Encyclopaedia (695 in the mp3 player dataset and 857 in the Restaurant Encyclopaedia dataset). Np _ agree and Ng _ agree are the number of pairs consistently labeled with the Pool Encyclopaedia or Gold Standard Encyclopaedia.

sections.heading: 5.4.2 Polarity Labelling Results.
sections.text: We have used the following methods for phrase-level polarity labeling in the experiment: • General: Make predictions by questioning the polarity of the word in general sentiment opinion sentences. • Optimize: The optimization approach proposed in (Lu et al. 2011) reduces the problem of polarity labeling to a limited linear programming. • General: Use our framework, except that the sentiment-sentiment orientation is determined by the corresponding overall rating. • Subaspect orientations of the ratings are determined by averaging the corresponding subaspect ratings. • Boost: Use our entire framework in which sentiment classification is performed on review text to increase sentiment polarity labeling.

sections.heading: 5.5 Parameter Analysis
sections.text: In the previous sections, we have weighted the different types of constraints equally for general experimental purposes. However, in this subsection, we will attempt to investigate the effects of different constraints within our framework by analyzing the four main parameters λ1 х λ4 in objective function (13).We will first conduct a "Knock Out One Term" experiment with these parameters to see if all of these constraints contribute to the performance of polarity marking at the phrase level. Furthermore, we will set one of the four parameters to 0 at a time and evaluate the F measure. The results will be shown in Table 5.The experimental result shows that singling out one of the four parameters reduces the performance of polarity marking. Furthermore, the restriction of the sentiment orientation at the review level (λ1) or the restriction of the general sentiment lexicon (λ2) greatly reduces the performance, which implies that these two information parameters are of great importance for the construction parameters.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: Treatment of numerical star rating as a sentiment indicator for review texts is a common assumption in previous phrase analysis algorithms (Lu et al. 2011; Lu, Zhai and Sundaresan 2009; Dave, Lawrence and Pennock 2003). However, in this paper we examined the inconsistency between numerical ratings and textual sentiment orientations. Our observations in valuation analysis show that users tend to make one-sided evaluations regardless of the text ratings they apply to a particular product. In addition, evaluation results are further verified using other methods to verify the existence of such bias and show the effectiveness of leverage of sensitization on reviews.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: The authors thank Prof. Xiaoyan Zhu, Yang Liu and Maosong Sun for the fruitful discussions as well as the anonymous critics for the constructive suggestions. The authors also thank the commentators Yunzhi Tan, Cheng Luo and Boya Wu for their careful comments. In the appendix of the objective function (13), let L = λ3Wa − λ4Ws, let us be the Lagrange multiplier for the constraint X ≥ 0, and let L (X) be the Lagrange function, then we have: Area size XL (X) = 2λ1ATAX − XiXi − 2AT (X − X0) + 2LX − 2WbXE − (15) By putting XL (X) = 0, we have the equation of XATAX − XiXi − XiXiXia- 2G (X − X0) + 2LX − WbXE (2001 − XV), the equation of XX + the equation of BATV (2001 − XXL), the equation of XX + the equation of XV (BATV).

metadata.abstractText: Sentiment analysis on user reviews helps to keep track of user reactions towards products, and make advices to users about what to buy. State-of-the-art review-level sentiment classification techniques could give pretty good precisions of above 90%. However, current phrase-level sentiment analysis approaches might only give sentiment polarity labelling precisions of around 70% ∼ 80%, which is far from satisfaction and restricts its application in many practical tasks. In this paper, we focus on the problem of phrase-level sentiment polarity labelling and attempt to bridge the gap between phrase-level and review-level sentiment analysis. We investigate the inconsistency between the numerical star ratings and the sentiment orientation of textual user reviews. Although they have long been treated as identical, which serves as a basic assumption in previous work, we find that this assumption is not necessarily true. We further propose to leverage the results of review-level sentiment classification to boost the performance of phrase-level polarity labelling using a novel constrained convex optimization framework. Besides, the framework is capable of integrating various kinds of information sources and heuristics, while giving the global optimal solution due to its convexity. Experimental results on both English and Chinese reviews show that our framework achieves high labelling precisions of up to 89%, which is a significant improvement from current approaches.
